page.title: 01LAND SOUTH WEST OF SHERBURN
page.content: An area of low lying fertile farmland originally post glacial Lake Pickering. Intensively cultivated wheat, potatoes, sugar beet. Kale and turnips for sheep. the land rises up in gentle slope until if forms the rather abrupt northern face of the Yorkshire Wolds. Rolling hills with only the steepest portionsd afforested for shelter although timber is produced from both private and forestry commission blocks. This block is quite well wooded. The plateau slopes gently on south side. Cultivated fields stretch to horizon. Barley for malting was once main crop but wheat and oil seed rape are prominent. About 7 farms. The long distance walk "Wolds Way" traverses northern escarpment of wolds. Quite a few tumuli as once used by stone age people when valleys were densley woode
